document.title: Indiana Academic Standards English Language Arts: Kindergarten

1E2D367116DC41499F58DA6015EF7216.description: Recognize common signs and logos and identify commercials or advertisements.

D2CDD496E4954684867BB1BEAA70C599.description: Give, restate, and follow simple two-step directions.

A24D07276F13452D800ADB6B5E2355B2.description: Speaking audibly, recite poems, rhymes, and songs, and use complete sentences to describe familiar people, places, things, and events and, with support, provide additional details.

E223A2B9F2894764A12B4E3327C91DBF.description: Ask appropriate questions about what a speaker says.

CB8C82B779244164B294225C4530090A.description: Ask and answer questions about key details in a text read aloud or information presented orally or through other media.

8C806D75B3C948418686A4227A2B543B.description: Continue a conversation through multiple exchanges.

B7C70FA63A154A7F8C57DBE7F4524D39.description: Ask questions to seek help, get information, or clarify something that is not understood.

A90FC5B9EF8A4423B2CEE8484E7B90FC.description: Listen to others, take turns speaking, and add one's own ideas to small group discussions or tasks.

9BDC2FCBAC5B4CCCB3A84007223448A2.description: Participate in collaborative conversations about grade-appropriate topics and texts with peers and adults in small and larger groups.

81C3B2F20262419CBC545E466FB6EA86.description: Listen actively and communicate effectively with a variety of audiences and for different purposes.

FD72D6B1166F44D1955A89F534B05278.description: Spelling – Spelling simple words phonetically, drawing on phonemic awareness.

7F586614E0A9448A8E7723191EF7A1C2.description: Punctuation – Recognizing and naming end punctuation.

E6996D642B094730AE5EDF691A0B3E30.description: Capitalization – Capitalizing the first word in a sentence and the pronoun I.

798B395DAC9A46FD9051C4D2EAC4A1D8.description: Demonstrate command of capitalization, punctuation, and spelling, focusing on:

BB179095AB824FEE9755B672E4AFE3C4.description: Usage – Recognizing that there are different kinds of sentences (e.g., sentences that tell something, sentences that ask something, etc.).

3D5C23F8B3264D82B2EA83225C39A56C.description: Prepositions – Standard begins at fourth grade.

70138AE68E484EFDB304743B25928335.description: Adjectives/ Adverbs – Standard begins at second grade.

A6420D753F4844AFB04F81D34FA4855D.description: Verbs – Writing sentences that include verbs.

846388987CEA4EF08A2AC8C548E6D30B.description: Nouns/Pronouns – Writing sentences that include singular and/or plural nouns (e.g., dog/dogs, cat/cats).

9C5408B52FB747B7B14CCBE61D56DEA6.description: Demonstrate command of English grammar and usage, focusing on:

27C9640FEEA74726B3332C9FA7EA0CEC.description: Conventions of Standard English: Grammar and Usage / Capitalization, Punctuation, and Spelling

2F8D880538E84995BB747DF2B307BEC6.description:
With support, build understanding of a topic using various sources.
  • Identify relevant pictures, charts, grade-appropriate texts, personal experiences, or people as sources of information on a topic.

689C7902A20C46FC9FD9160599EEA38F.description: The Research Process: Finding, Assessing, Synthesizing, and Reporting Information

E42AAF225CBA46BAB936AEE21C42F5CF.description:
Apply the writing process to –
  • With support, revise writing by adding simple details; review (edit) writing for format and conventions (e.g., correct spelling of simple words, capitalization of the first word of the sentence).
  • Use available technology to produce and publish writing.

243ADF4F7FF64CCB8E924CE90D083B18.description: Use words and pictures to narrate a single event or simple story, arranging ideas in order.

C8BEEFA225134B4EBEEBAF7685A0DB8A.description: Use words and pictures to develop a main idea and provide some information about a topic.

56B553E592444953A5E971D5FCCC7E08.description: Use words and pictures to provide logical reasons for suggesting that others follow a particular course of action.

DCB7C3985A56427CBD53A3E2F8576C4C.description: Writing Genres: Argumentative, Informative, and Narrative

FD336C11F25C4C90AA923C04D01C3807.description: Write by moving from left to right and top to bottom.

FD4D51FE24A44E41ADB98B4AD2AACCF3.description: Write most uppercase (capital) and lowercase letters of the alphabet, correctly shaping and spacing the letters of the words.

089A32E560FA4488B5D3F4DF0ED624D3.description: Write for specific purposes and audiences.

0089D6C2437A43849170F242AB234C0D.description: With support, ask and answer questions about unknown words in a nonfiction text.

51826F00DC0C430AA581E60CA84FBBCA.description: With support, ask and answer questions about unknown words in stories, poems, or songs.

0BD8C02059AA4DBEB448BCE4CD155828.description: Vocabulary in Literature and Nonfiction Texts

EFE72AEE1B2D4613AD10B380D7652C7E.description: Recognize frequently occurring inflections (e.g., look, looks).

53B25D5E21DC4757BBEDFA588E96B41C.description: Identify and sort pictures of objects into categories (e.g., colors, shapes, opposites).

0D86AB10F47142BEB0F6760DF6EEDF1E.description: Use words, phrases, and strategies acquired through conversations, reading and being read to, and responding to literature and nonfiction texts to build and apply vocabulary.

F8911BB6629C4A7BA5C3229EC9F3429C.description: With support, identify basic similarities in and differences between two texts on the same topic.

59B6315F4926472381FC85334D0873A0.description: With support, identify the reasons an author gives to support points in a text.

7A9FF30D5A864AC6BC02A011CD6C5E64.description: Recognize that a nonfiction text can be structured to describe a topic.

D3406167A7394EB2BF5CD84EB6ED67A1.description: Identify text features of a nonfiction text (e.g., title, author, illustrations) and describe the relationship between those features and the text in which they appear.

F1BEDCCFB7E948EC9957F8AA06199EEB.description: With support, describe the connection between two individuals, events, ideas, or pieces of information in a text.

655E58C0E68F429283B110CE39597A36.description: With support, retell the main idea and key details of a text.

66366AD043B646C387077BBCEF7E842F.description: With support, ask and answer questions about important elements of a text (e.g., events, topics, concepts).

AB88CB439AF54993A3C75E4B84102266.description: Actively engage in group reading activities with purpose and understanding.

0342119E11CC406AB44D20F12156F71C.description: With support, compare and contrast the adventures and experiences of characters in familiar stories.

F9E54E2C88074DC5A348C35D711A922C.description: With support, describe the relationship between illustrations and the story in which they appear.

A94C609F08BE4E65B6B11CBC05A77D36.description: With support, define the role of the author and illustrator of a story in telling the story.

90C8C9D0EF654126854D50B4FE7657DA.description: Recognize familiar narrative text genres (e.g., fairy tales, nursery rhymes, storybooks).

A12DC2F4F0C04429B8F8CC399370C25C.description: Make predictions about what will happen in a story.

4D09C6B7099841F1B0D7ED034D36660D.description: Identify important elements of the text (e.g., characters, settings, or events).

9FB84D2C8C85425CB6085576EB7BB64F.description: With support, retell familiar stories, poems, and nursery rhymes, including key details.

13FD5475D8CE4FE3BE5C8706BF045333.description: With support, ask and answer questions about main topics and key details in a text heard or read. Further guidance for support will be provided in the Literacy Framework.

A64879F49AAC496686EEB7A061ABBCD9.description: Actively engage in group reading activities with purpose and understanding.

A6AA58DB8894403D8DB7E4C9C0143A81.description: Orally read emergent-reader texts, maintaining an appropriate pace and using self-correcting strategies while reading.

77A69E73B2544FEA874C3098288DB411.description: Identify similarities and differences in words (e.g., word endings, onset and rime) when spoken or written.

71DC21BE2DE8415590FB2A231DD58F7D.description: Read common high-frequency words by sight (e.g., a, my).

74918A69D2114FD999030D121400A962.description: Recognize the long and short sounds for the five major vowels.

8FFC834D1889493D98BB7DFAB5BDDB05.description: Blend consonant-vowel-consonant (CVC) sounds to make words.

E643A775BAFF41BCB47C99EF1C759B2E.description: Use letter-sound knowledge to decode the sound of each consonant (e.g., dog = /d/ /g/; soap = /s/ /p/).

6DC6863DD6924113B37BE82F9503CAB0.description: Add, delete, or substitute sounds to change one-syllable words.

D6DA77076EB34DE3A3F7D7C320CC7144.description: Tell the order of sounds heard in words with two or three phonemes, and identify the beginning, middle (medial) and final sounds.

496888D81F1445EEA7AA3DF5BD8E9D84.description: Orally blend the onset (the initial sound) and the rime (the vowel and ending sound) in words.

F4F66FAD781A49EDBC5ABCC1BD7DF05F.description: Orally pronounce, blend, and segment words into syllables.

E68F3CA4EF5F47FA841D1DDC80C11292.description: Identify and name all uppercase (capital) and lowercase letters of the alphabet.

1673CC0ADD904B8B9E44F5F39AC5F468.description: Recognize that words are combined to form sentences.

B867298AB5B84A968688A97CCC6CFA20.description: Recognize that written words are made up of sequences of letters.

E547E9655D5B49E490B907ED5CA90AB9.description: Demonstrate understanding that print moves from left to right across the page and from top to bottom.

1E2280154C3A4AAB8961F2097586B6E2.description: Understand and apply knowledge of print concepts, phonics, phonemic awareness, vocabulary, and fluency and comprehension as a foundation for developing reading skills.
